Abstract: This study delves into the multifaceted dimensions of firearms law, extending beyond the conventional focus on physical harm to explore broader legal and societal implications. By examining the Second Amendment, the research highlights the complex interplay between individual rights and public safety. It scrutinizes self-defense doctrines and their legal interpretations, revealing how they shape societal norms and influence legislative frameworks. The analysis also considers the role of scholarship in informing policy debates and public perceptions about gun ownership and regulation. Through a comprehensive review of legal precedents and scholarly discourse, this work aims to provide a nuanced understanding of firearms law, advocating for informed policy-making that balances constitutional rights with the imperative of reducing gun violence.
